name.text: 001 Do this online reading: Sections 5.5 through 5.7 of How to Think Like a Computer Scientist: Learning with Python 3 by Peter Wentworth, Jeffrey Elkner, Allen B. Downey, and Chris Meyers, doing the next set of questions while you do so.

questiontext.text: Do this online reading: Sections 5.5 through 5.7 of How to Think Like a Computer Scientist: Learning with Python 3 by Peter Wentworth, Jeffrey Elkner, Allen B. Downey, and Chris Meyers, doing the next set of questions while you do so.

name.text:
002 Consider the following code.

What statement should be added in the box so the function prints Banana! only if the value of n is larger than 20?

questiontext.text:
Consider the following code.

What statement should be added in the box so the function prints Banana! only if the value of n is larger than 20?

name.text:
003 Consider the following code.

What statements should be in boxes A, B, and C so that the sequence correctly prints either 'A won', 'B won', or 'Game tied' given scoreA (the score of player A) and scoreB (the score of player B).

questiontext.text:
Consider the following code.

What statements should be in boxes A, B, and C so that the sequence correctly prints either 'A won', 'B won', or 'Game tied' given scoreA (the score of player A) and scoreB (the score of player B).

name.text: 005 Versions 1 and 2 will print the same thing given the same x and y.

questiontext.text: Versions 1 and 2 will print the same thing given the same x and y.

name.text: 006 Which of the versions runs faster?

questiontext.text: Which of the versions runs faster?

name.text: 007 Which of the versions is better?

questiontext.text: Which of the versions is better?

name.text: 008 Watch The Accumulator Pattern (revisited).

questiontext.text: Watch The Accumulator Pattern (revisited).

name.text: 015 Choose the correct options to produce a function that returns the sum 2 + 4 + 6 + ... + 2n. (For example, this function should return 2 + 4 + 6 + 8, which is 20, when n is 4.)

questiontext.text: Choose the correct options to produce a function that returns the sum 2 + 4 + 6 + ... + 2n. (For example, this function should return 2 + 4 + 6 + 8, which is 20, when n is 4.)

name.text: 016 Watch First Solve a Concrete Example By Hand.

questiontext.text: Watch First Solve a Concrete Example By Hand.

name.text: 017 True or False: To solve a problem by writing computer code for it, you must understand the problem that you are solving.

questiontext.text: True or False: To solve a problem by writing computer code for it, you must understand the problem that you are solving.

name.text: 018 True or False: One excellent way to figure out how to code the problem that you are solving is to first solve a concrete example by hand..

questiontext.text: True or False: One excellent way to figure out how to code the problem that you are solving is to first solve a concrete example by hand..

name.text: 019 In choosing a concrete example to solve by hand, you should (check all that apply):

questiontext.text: In choosing a concrete example to solve by hand, you should (check all that apply):

answer.text: Choose numbers that make the calculations easy.
Avoid anything that may lead to a special case.

name.text: 020 As you solve the problem by hand, using the concrete example that you have chosen, you should (check all that apply):

questiontext.text: As you solve the problem by hand, using the concrete example that you have chosen, you should (check all that apply):

answer.text: Keep track of how you calculated each item, or at least be able to figure out afterwards how you calculated it.

name.text: 021 Online Reading: What is Unit Testing? (reading appears in the top image on the right-hand side of the page)

questiontext.text: Online Reading: What is Unit Testing? (reading appears in the top image on the right-hand side of the page)

name.text: 022 Explain briefly, in your own words: What is unit testing?

questiontext.text: Explain briefly, in your own words: What is unit testing?

name.text: 023 Online Reading: Code the Unit Test First.

questiontext.text: Online Reading: Code the Unit Test First.

name.text: 024 Which of the following is typically faster?

questiontext.text: Which of the following is typically faster?

answer.text: Code the unit tests for a function, then code the function itself.
Code the function, then code the unit tests for that function.
The two approaches are equally fast.

name.text: 025 Writing the unit tests first helps you better understand the problem for which you are writing code.

questiontext.text: Writing the unit tests first helps you better understand the problem for which you are writing code.
